Its largest source of funding comes from hundreds of thousands of small individual donors, with notable surges during events like the 2020 George Floyd protests (e.g., raising around $41–42 million in 2020 from nearly 468,000 donors). It operates a revolving bail fund where donations are used to pay bail, which is typically refunded by courts and reused. Institutional support includes grants from The Audacious Project (a TED-hosted initiative backed by major philanthropists) and mentions of family foundations like the David Rockefeller Fund. Related bail fund networks have received funding from sources like Open Philanthropy (funded by Dustin Moskovitz and Cari Tuna) and MacKenzie Scott, though these are not directly confirmed for The Bail Project itself. The organization does not publicly list specific major donors in detail on its site or annual reports, emphasizing broad community support through monthly "Freedom Funders" and online contributions. Financial transparency is provided via annual reports and IRS Form 990 filings, showing cumulative bail postings exceeding $91 million as of recent reports, supported entirely by donations (no government funding is prominently mentioned, except isolated past local grants criticized by opponents).","sender":"AGENT","grokMode":"NORMAL","mediaUrls":[],"deepsearchHeaders":[{"header":"","steps":[{"finalMessage":"The","toolUsageCardResults":[{"toolUsageCardId":"d9af3a30-a150-4a2b-990a-398080ca3acb"},{"toolUsageCardId":"1dfa4ba5-5ae7-495d-96e1-ddcf5b70100e"},{"toolUsageCardId":"d1141c1f-c784-4ae4-8a59-5c6addb05910"},{"toolUsageCardId":"37889ef6-bb7c-4a95-90d8-d1e3261bd4ce"},{"toolUsageCardId":"8d1f4303-9d38-4a76-b202-ee8d60b1cf91"},{"toolUsageCardId":"ee006220-632b-4ec4-b936-d51a49fbd895"},{"toolUsageCardId":"d9af3a30-a150-4a2b-990a-398080ca3acb","webResults":[{"url":"https://www.audaciousproject.org/grantees/the-bail-project","title":"The Bail Project | The Audacious Project","snippet":"The Bail Project has a bold idea: to eliminate cash bail and make the criminal justice system in the US fair for all. items.message:
The Bail Project is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization primarily funded by **private donations from individuals and philanthropic foundations**.

- Its largest source of funding comes from **hundreds of thousands of small individual donors**, with notable surges during events like the 2020 George Floyd protests (e.g., raising around $41â€“42 million in 2020 from nearly 468,000 donors).
- It operates a revolving bail fund where donations are used to pay bail, which is typically refunded by courts and reused.
- Institutional support includes grants from **The Audacious Project** (a TED-hosted initiative backed by major philanthropists) and mentions of family foundations like the David Rockefeller Fund.
- Related bail fund networks have received funding from sources like **Open Philanthropy** (funded by Dustin Moskovitz and Cari Tuna) and **MacKenzie Scott**, though these are not directly confirmed for The Bail Project itself.
- The organization does not publicly list specific major donors in detail on its site or annual reports, emphasizing broad community support through monthly "Freedom Funders" and online contributions.

Financial transparency is provided via annual reports and IRS Form 990 filings, showing cumulative bail postings exceeding $91 million as of recent reports, supported entirely by donations (no government funding is prominently mentioned, except isolated past local grants criticized by opponents).

# Role Definition:
You are an expert product photographer and creative art director specializing in high-end luxury goods. Your sole task is to generate a photorealistic image of a custom 3D subsurface laser-engraved crystal ornament based on a simple subject provided by the user.
# Core Directive:
The user will provide only the [Subject]. You must autonomously analyze this subject to determine the most aesthetically appropriate and enhancing configuration for the entire scene. You must decide on the crystal's shape, the base material, the surrounding environment, and the lighting mood to best complement the vibe of the user's subject.
# Creative Analysis Logic (Art Director Instructions):
Analyze the Vibe: Is the subject elegant (e.g., ballerina, swan), cozy (e.g., sleeping cat, family photo), powerful (e.g., lion, sports car), or architectural?
Determine Crystal Shape:
Elegant/Tall Subjects -> Use a tall, multi-faceted prism or diamond shape to enhance verticality.
Solid/Cozy Subjects -> Use a hefty, thick rectangular block or cube to convey weight and warmth.
Dynamic Subjects -> Use complex geometric shapes with many bevels to refract light dramatically.
Determine Environment & Lighting:
Elegant Vibe: Place it in a luxurious, dark, moody environment (art gallery, velvet study). Use dramatic, cool ambient light contrasting with warmth from the base.
Cozy/Warm Vibe: Place it in a homey, soft environment (wooden desk, near a fireplace). Use warm, soft, golden-hour lighting with cozy bokeh.
Modern/Tech Vibe: Place it on a sleek, minimalist surface (polished concrete, dark glass). Use clean, neutral lighting.
# Image Generation Template (Mandatory Technical Specs):
Whatever artistic choices you make based on the logic above, the final image MUST adhere to these technical specifications to ensure a realistic "3D Laser Engraving" look:
Engraving Style: The subject inside must NOT look like a solid 3D print. It MUST be described as a "volumetric white point-cloud engraving," having a "frosty, granular, subsurface texture" made of millions of micro-cracks inside the glass.
Lighting Interaction: The engraving must "glow brilliantly from within," illuminated entirely by warm, golden LED light originating from the base beneath it.
Material: The crystal must be heavy, clear, flawless K9 optical glass with beveled edges that catch and split the light.
Photography Style: Cinematic product photograph, macro lens, extremely shallow depth of field (bokeh), 8k resolution, hyper-detailed.
# Input Process:
I will now provide the subject. You will instantly apply the creative logic and generate the final image.

result.text:
Yann is just plain incorrectÂ here, heâ€™s confusing general intelligence with universal intelligence.

Brains are the most exquisâ€‹ite and complex phenomena we know of in the universe (so far), and they are in fact extremely general.

Obviously one canâ€™t circumvent the no free lunch theorem so in a practical and finite system there always has to be some degree of specialisation around the â€‹targetÂ distribution that is being learnt.

But the point about generality is that in theory, in the Turing Machine senseâ€‹, the architecture of â€‹sâ€‹uch a general system is capable of learning anything computable given enough time and memoryâ€‹ (and data), and the human brain (and AI foundation models) are approximate Turing Machines.

Finally, with â€‹regards toÂ â€‹Yann'sÂ comments about chess players, itâ€™sÂ amazing that humans could have invented chess â€‹in the first placeÂ (and all the other â€‹aâ€‹spects â€‹oâ€‹f modern civilizationÂ â€‹from science to 747s!) let alone get as brilliant at it as someone like Magnus. He may not be â€‹strictlyÂ optimal (after all he has finite memory and limited time to make a decision)Â but itâ€™s incredible what he and we can do with our brains given they were evolved for hunter gathering.

{"component_objects":{"details_1":{"type":"grok_share","data":{"profile_user":{"id_str":"44196397","profile_image_url_https":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1995407795835772928/Wp7m4L9h.jpg","name":"Elon Musk","screen_name":"elonmusk","highlighted_label":{"description":"X","badge":{"url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1955359038532653056/OSHY3ewP_bigger.jpg"},"url":{"urlType":"DeepLink","url":"https://twitter.com/X"},"userLabelType":"BusinessLabel","userLabelDisplayType":"Badge"},"verified":false,"is_blue_verified":true},"grok_user":{"id_str":"1720665183188922368","profile_image_url_https":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1893219113717342208/Vgg2hEPa.jpg","name":"Grok","screen_name":"grok","highlighted_label":{"description":"xAI","badge":{"url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1769430779845611520/lIgjSJGU_bigger.jpg"},"url":{"urlType":"DeepLink","url":"https://twitter.com/xai"},"userLabelType":"BusinessLabel","userLabelDisplayType":"Badge"},"verified":false,"is_blue_verified":true,"verified_type":"Business"},"id":"cdus00xAX3tFLTgN2bSSW74vZ","conversation_preview":[{"message":"So what’s the best way to improve?","sender":"USER","grokMode":"NORMAL","mediaUrls":[]},{"message":"The best way to improve performance—whether in sports, skills, work, or personal development—is to prioritize process goals over outcome or performance goals, according to strong evidence from sports psychology research. A 2022 meta-analysis of 27 studies (Williamson et al.) found that: Process goals (focusing on technique, strategy, or controllable actions) had the largest effect on performance improvement (Cohen's d = 1.36, a very large effect). Performance goals (e.g., achieving a specific time, score, or personal best) had a moderate effect (d = 0.44). Outcome goals (e.g., winning, beating others, or final rankings) had almost no effect (d = 0.09). Process goals work better because they're fully under your control, reduce anxiety from uncontrollable factors (like opponents or conditions), direct attention to executable actions, build self-efficacy, and promote consistent effort and persistence. Practical Steps to Improve Effectively Focus primarily on process goals Identify the specific behaviors, techniques, or habits that drive better results. - Examples in running: "Maintain relaxed shoulders and quick cadence during strides" instead of "Run a sub-20-minute 5K." - In writing/public speaking: "Practice deep breathing before starting" instead of "Deliver a flawless presentation." - In learning a skill: "Spend 30 minutes daily on deliberate technique drills" instead of "Master this by next month." Use a hierarchy of goals - Set 1 big outcome goal for direction and motivation (e.g., "Win the league" or "Get promoted"). - Break it into performance goals as milestones (e.g., "Improve my average score by 10% this season"). - Drive everything with multiple process goals (the daily/weekly actions that make the above possible). Make goals SMART where it fits SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) is great for making process and performance goals concrete and trackable. - Bad: "Get better at free throws." - Good (process): "Practice 100 free throws with proper form 4 days per week for the next month." Track progress and adjust regularly Review weekly: What processes did you execute? What worked? Tweak as needed—flexibility prevents frustration. Feedback (from a coach, data, or self-review) amplifies goal effectiveness. Combine with other proven habits - Deliberate practice (focused, effortful repetition with feedback). - Consistency over intensity. - Build intrinsic motivation by emphasizing mastery and enjoyment of the process. Obsessing over outcomes often leads to pressure and suboptimal performance. By shifting attention to controllable processes, you build better habits, stay motivated longer, and—paradoxically—achieve better outcomes as a byproduct. This approach is backed not just by the 2022 meta-analysis but aligns with decades of goal-setting theory in psychology. Start small, stack process wins, and improvement compounds.","sender":"AGENT","grokMode":"NORMAL","mediaUrls":[],"deepsearchHeaders":[{"header":"","steps":[{"finalMessage":"The","toolUsageCardResults":[{"toolUsageCardId":"465797ce-4103-4fa1-aadc-ee0b65f9a867"},{"toolUsageCardId":"d8ed1ee7-787c-4ffc-a76a-b0eac471599d"},{"toolUsageCardId":"eb5d8156-3935-489e-8c32-d450cd9c5265"},{"toolUsageCardId":"b2221879-93a4-4524-b5f4-89e324b98df9"},{"toolUsageCardId":"75438891-c472-4955-a257-23ac4707700a"},{"toolUsageCardId":"465797ce-4103-4fa1-aadc-ee0b65f9a867","webResults":[{"url":"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/1750984X.2022.2116723","title":"Full article: The performance and psychological effects of goal setting in sport: A systematic review and meta-analysis","snippet":"Therefore, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis that synthesised the effects of goal setting on task performance and various psychological and psychophysiological outcomes in sport. Searches returned 17,841 articles, with 27 meeting eligibility criteria. A meta-analysis of the performance effects and a narrative synthesis of the psychological and psychophysiological effects were undertaken. Process goals had the largest effect on performance (d = 1.36) compared to performance goals (d = 0.44) and outcome goals (d = 0.09).","language":"en","description":"A meta-analysis of the performance ... effects were undertaken. Process goals had the largest effect on performance (d = 1.36) compared to performance goals (d = 0.44) and outcome goals (d = 0.09)....","siteName":"Taylor & Francis Online","image":"https://imgs.search.brave.com/kHA-IRmWyHgGg7zTs97E4hwSnUMIPSvtzPKIadVSzt4/rs:fit:200:200:1:0/g:ce/aHR0cHM6Ly9jb3Zl/cnMudGFuZGYuY28u/dWsvb2cvUklSUy5w/bmc","favicon":"https://imgs.search.brave.com/c7W_Kupq5D7KZH6hkMKLLW3AJryuSf2xG5VktcGGNK4/rs:fit:32:32:1:0/g:ce/aHR0cDovL2Zhdmlj/b25zLnNlYXJjaC5i/cmF2ZS5jb20vaWNv/bnMvNjkyY2E0YjNi/NWQyZmRlZmM0NTFm/MDg1ODliOWQ4NTEw/MWVjYWVmMjdlMWE0/ODc3NzhjYmQ0YWIy/NmY3ODFkMS93d3cu/dGFuZGZvbmxpbmUu/Y29tLw"},{"url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/363251445_The_performance_and_psychological_effects_of_goal_setting_in_sport_A_systematic_review_and_meta-analysis","title":"(PDF) The performance and psychological effects of goal setting in sport: A systematic review and meta-analysis","snippet":"Therefore, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis that synthesised the effects of goal setting on task performance and various psychological and psychophysiological outcomes in sport. items.message: So whatâ€™s the best way to improve?

The best way to improve performanceâ€”whether in sports, skills, work, or personal developmentâ€”is to **prioritize process goals** over outcome or performance goals, according to strong evidence from sports psychology research.

A 2022 meta-analysis of 27 studies (Williamson et al.) found that:
- **Process goals** (focusing on technique, strategy, or controllable actions) had the largest effect on performance improvement (Cohen's d = 1.36, a very large effect).
- **Performance goals** (e.g., achieving a specific time, score, or personal best) had a moderate effect (d = 0.44).
- **Outcome goals** (e.g., winning, beating others, or final rankings) had almost no effect (d = 0.09).

Process goals work better because they're fully under your control, reduce anxiety from uncontrollable factors (like opponents or conditions), direct attention to executable actions, build self-efficacy, and promote consistent effort and persistence.

### Practical Steps to Improve Effectively
1. **Focus primarily on process goals**  
   Identify the specific behaviors, techniques, or habits that drive better results.  
   - Examples in running: "Maintain relaxed shoulders and quick cadence during strides" instead of "Run a sub-20-minute 5K."  
   - In writing/public speaking: "Practice deep breathing before starting" instead of "Deliver a flawless presentation."  
   - In learning a skill: "Spend 30 minutes daily on deliberate technique drills" instead of "Master this by next month."

2. **Use a hierarchy of goals**  
   - Set 1 big **outcome goal** for direction and motivation (e.g., "Win the league" or "Get promoted").  
   - Break it into **performance goals** as milestones (e.g., "Improve my average score by 10% this season").  
   - Drive everything with multiple **process goals** (the daily/weekly actions that make the above possible).

3. **Make goals SMART where it fits**  
   SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) is great for making process and performance goals concrete and trackable.  
   - Bad: "Get better at free throws."  
   - Good (process): "Practice 100 free throws with proper form 4 days per week for the next month."

4. **Track progress and adjust regularly**  
   Review weekly: What processes did you execute? What worked? Tweak as neededâ€”flexibility prevents frustration. Feedback (from a coach, data, or self-review) amplifies goal effectiveness.

5. **Combine with other proven habits**  
   - Deliberate practice (focused, effortful repetition with feedback).  
   - Consistency over intensity.  
   - Build intrinsic motivation by emphasizing mastery and enjoyment of the process.

Obsessing over outcomes often leads to pressure and suboptimal performance. By shifting attention to controllable processes, you build better habits, stay motivated longer, andâ€”paradoxicallyâ€”achieve better outcomes as a byproduct. This approach is backed not just by the 2022 meta-analysis but aligns with decades of goal-setting theory in psychology. Start small, stack process wins, and improvement compounds.

Gavin Newsom caught in a massive federal money laundering scam
â€Œ
Newsom increased ambulance costs 300%, then requested reimbursements from the federal government, but it was fake
â€Œ
Heâ€™d then pay a different company a fraction of the cost and pocket the rest. Stealing billions

â€œOne of the largest and most convoluted schemes in modern history has been discovered during a review of California's medical financial recordsâ€

â€œInvestigators found that under Gavin Newsom's leadership, the Golden State has essentially been funneling taxpayer money from all across America to prop up California's own finances. 

Genesis Plan started in 2022 and it revolves around the complex concept of intergovernmental transfers, which in simple terms is when a local hospital or county makes a transfer to the state Medicaid agency for payments of medical services such as ambulance rides

- After the transfers are made, the state can then request a matching amount of money from the federal government

- But Gavin Newsom's California abused this system by raising the price of a simple ambulance ride by nearly 300%
- Then once the local hospitals made the transfer to the state and the state received the matching funds from the federal government
- California then instead paid a private ambulance service which cost only a fraction of the original price, pocketing the difference.â€

This is one of the most dishonest frauds against taxpayers ever created, Gavin Newsom stole billions with this fraud 

Gavin Newsom reimbursement rates for public ambulance services by up to 500% (from $339 to $1,600 per ride in some approvals), prompting local governments or hospitals to transfer those inflated amounts to the state via IGTs. 

The state then claims federal matching dollars, typically at a 50% rate, before reimbursing private ambulance providers at the original lower cost, effectively pocketing the surplus federal funds to offset state budget shortfalls

It's time to hold Gavin Newsom and California Democrats accountable

items.message:
- The post accuses California Governor Gavin Newsom of masterminding a "Genesis Plan" since 2022 to defraud federal taxpayers by inflating ambulance ride costs up to 500% via intergovernmental transfers (IGTs), securing matching Medicaid funds, then reimbursing providers at lower rates to pocket billions.
- This echoes documented criticisms of California's Ground Emergency Medical Transportation (GEMT) program, where public ambulances receive 3-5 times higher payments than private ones without state general-fund spending, generating federal matches exceeding $1 billion annually, per Paragon Health Institute analysis from December 2025.
- Though the IGT mechanism is legal, it's widely condemned as a fiscal loophole that distorts markets and burdens federal budgets; the post's dramatic framing, including unverified "Genesis Plan" details, amplifies a viral conservative narrative originating in October 2025 without evidence of criminal charges against Newsom.

I realize more and more that there is such a thing as dumb person in life. 

â€œTurn off the lights and vision fails, LiDAR keeps workingâ€ may sound logical in theory, but the Waymo SF power outage really just disproved it. 

During the recent San Francisco power outage, Waymoâ€™s entire LiDAR-heavy robotaxi fleet went offline. Literally the entire fleet just stopped operating. Meanwhile, all Tesla Robotaxis kept running! 

Teslaâ€™s vision-based system is trained on billions of miles, neural nets, and, most importantly, doesnâ€™t require a city to be perfectly powered to function. An alien UFO could land in the middle of nowhere with the entire city blacked out and it will still work. 

Humans donâ€™t drive with lasers.

We drive with our eyes, we process what we see with our brain, and then we react with our body.

Tesla does the same thing, except the brain is AI, trained on billions of real-world miles. Teslaâ€™s Vision system learns the world as it is, adapts in real time, and improves continuously and is NOT dependent on special maps, perfect lighting, or city-by-city infrastructure like LiDAR.

Thatâ€™s why it scales.

With a simple software update, Teslaâ€™s Vision AI can operate anywhere instead of just where the environment was pre-approved or carefully controlled like LiDAR. 

This is how generalized real-world autonomy gets solved. I believe this will be obvious in hindsight.

result.text:
Elon Musk: A lot of the negativity stems from the axiomatic flaw that the economic pie is static, that it's a zero-sum game.

â€œAt my first company I didn't have any money, I just had $100,000 in student debt. That was a company in the very early days, of the Internet, called Zip2. But for all companies subsequently, I basically doubled down. I took the money from Zip2, invested it in X.com-PayPal, and then took the PayPal money, invested that in creating Tesla and SpaceX. It didn't feel right that I should ask investors to invest if I was not prepared to invest my own money. I think the whole other people's money thing is not right. You want to have skin in the game. As a result of that, I own a lot of shares in the company. And the better the company does, the more valuable the shares are. But that's because the pie has grown. And so you have to say what's at the root of a lot of the negativity is an axiomatic flaw. That the pie is static, that it's a zero-sum game, that if someone else succeeds, it's because they took more than their fair share of this fixed pie. But it's not a fixed pie. Obviously, the economic pie has grown considerably from what it was in the past. The output of goods and services, the productivity per person is dramatically greater than it has been in the past. So when you create a new company and you create new products and services, you're growing the amount of goods and services available to people. So you've not taken anything away from anyone. You've created something new and you've given people new products and services they didn't have before. We didn't use to have an iPhone, we didn't use to have computers. We didn't use to have cars or be able to fly in airplanes. We didn't use to have many of the life-saving medicines that we have today. These are all new things. The pie has grown tremendously.â€

From: Interview with Ben Shapiro, January 24, 2024
